results.title: Violence on the screen
results.creator_credit: Cathy Johnstone and Video Education Australia
results.brief_description: The issue about whether violence on the screen and in the media influences the behaviour of the community, especially children, is a contentious one. This program, comprising of two videos - ‘I wrote to Steven Spielberg’ and ‘Bobo dolls and copy cats’, as well as video support notes, attempts to provide a well rounded introduction to the complexities of the debate. Many questions are raised and discussed, but it should be noted that due to the complex nature of the subject, a definitive answer cannot be reached. The program discusses the difference between real, fictional and implied violence. Discusses the notion of intent, including the difficult areas of comedy and cartoon violence, as well as the impact of television news. It introduces the idea that one effect of viewing violence may be an altered perception of the amount of violence in the world. It discusses the role of Australia’s film and television classification system; asks whether violence is always bad, and asks students to consider whether children are an especially susceptible audience. It also introduces the notion that violence in the media may serve cultural, psychological or historical needs, and asks students to consider whether it’s violence in the media or other factors in people’s lives that are more important in determining actions. Suitable for middle to senior secondary school students in Media Studies, English, and related Studies of Society and Environment.

results.title: Violence in the Cinema.....Part 1
results.creator_credit: George Miller, Byron Kennedy, Acta Scienta and Warlok Films
results.brief_description: A graphic satire on the representation of violence in the cinema, this early work by George Miller has “psychologist and media critic”, Dr. Edgar Fine, providing an academic account on the various theories around this subject. What starts as a fairly didactic and dry discourse on violence in the cinema takes a turn for the gruesomely demonstrative. Brutal acts are performed in visceral detail. This short by Miller was also his first collaboration with producer Byron Kennedy, whom he met at the University of New South Wales. The success of this collaboration led them to form the production company Kennedy Miller and to embody their fascination with violence in the feature film, ‘Mad Max’ (1979).

results.title: Vintage: A History of Wine. Eps. 9 & 10
results.creator_credit: Christopher Ralling, Michael Gill, Channel 4, Malone Gill Productions and WGBH (Boston)
results.brief_description: The power of the purse recounts the rise of Bordeaux as the prime wine producing area of France in the eighteenth century. Massive investment by the nouveaux riches led to the rise of Chateaux Latour, Lafite and Margaux and others who based their success on well-drained soil and insistence on the latest and best cellar techniques. “The devastator” describes the catastrophic effect on the French wine industry of phylloxera which wiped out almost all of the vineyards. Scientific investigations by Pasteur and Planchon solved the problem and introduced new techniques to viticulture.

results.title: Setting the scene iPod tour: designer interviews
results.brief_description: A joint production with AFTRS, this is a series of four interviews with Australian production designers for the walking tour part of ACMI’s Setting the Scene exhibition. Roger Ford talks about Mon Oncle and The Terminal, Owen Paterson on Fritz Lang’s Metropolis, Chris Kennedy on Stanley Kubrick’s The Shining and Stephen Curtis on Peter Greenaway’s The Cook, the thief, his wife and her lover.

results.title: Setting the scene designer interviews: Stephen Curtis
results.brief_description: A co-production between AFTRS and ACMI for ACMI’s Setting the Scene exhibition. Stephen Curtis talks about his approach to production designing on his work on Bedevil and Night Cries. This was used as part of the Landscape Spaces section of the exhibition.

results.title: Winter of our dreams
results.creator_credit: John Duigan, Richard Mason and Vega Film Productions
results.brief_description: An unstable relationship develops between prostitute Louise (Judy Davis), and a married man Rob (Bryan Brown), following the suicide of a mutual friend, Lisa. Lou (Davis), who is left with Lisa’s diaries becomes infatuated by her friend’s life and unrequited passion for Rob. She attempts to assume Lisa’s identity, in appearance, thoughts and actions, which poses the viewer with the question, will she too end her life? Lou sees in Rob an avenue for salvation from her life of drug addiction and prostitution. It is a destructive relationship, with Rob giving her little encouragement or hope. Rob is drawn to Lou for the possible insight she can offer into the years that passed between his sudden departure from Lisa and his now, unconventional marriage. Ultimately, it is a one sided relationship and Lou must decide whether she can make something of her life. Cast includes Bryan Brown, Judy Davis, Cathy Downes and Baz Luhrmann.

results.title: Two bagatelles
results.creator_credit: Grant Munro, Norman McLaren and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Two short Norman McLaren films in which animation technique is employed with live actors. In the first, entitled On the Lawn, a male dancer waltzes to synthetic music. The second is a fast march, In the Backyard, accompanied by an old-fashioned calliope.

results.title: Two-lane blacktop [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Monte Hellman, Michael S Laughlin and Universal Pictures
results.brief_description: A young driver and his mechanic in a souped-up 1955 Chevrolet, living off drag racing bets in the south west, establish a tentative relationship with a girl who tags on to them. They become involved in an indeterminate cross-country race with the middle-aged driver of a new Pontiac GTO. Like other Hellman films, Two-lane Blacktop is a genre film in which the popular elements are not exploited to satisfy audience expectations but are subverted into fresh patterns. This makes it the most determinedly original of the post-Easy Rider road movies, an existential parable which makes striking use of widescreen compositions, long takes and elliptical cuts while denying narrative tension. Instead there is the resonance of character and situation. Hellman has described the film as ‘a love story (about) … how much romance is left in a non-romantic world’, but this is implicit. Cast includes: James Taylor, Warren Oates, Laurie Bird, Dennis Wilson. Also available on VHS.

results.title: Winter Express
results.creator_credit: Anthony Loeb and United States Information Agency
results.brief_description: The story of a one-man small town weekly newspaper and the man who run it in Winters, California. The publisher is also a reporter, editor, printer, and distributor. Tells how a weekly functions and how is reflects the virtues of a small town in the United States - an example of the free press.
